b"8. I won't go into more specifics, as I don't have the answer myself. But my gut tells me I am neuro-divergent (read as you will). My experience doesn't line up with Bipolar II, but does with other disorders  I'm taking my mental health into my own hands, finally. I'm speaking up"

b"7. In the last month I've made efforts to get healthy physically AND mentally. I've also accepted these symptoms I actually have may be part of something else.  And today, after explaining all this (and then some), my therapist agreed. Bipolar isn't the whole story"

b"6. I pushed away any thoughts questioning my dx until a few months ago. IDR the exact impetus, but I remember thinking, again, that bipolar symptoms don't feel like me.  I did my own research, but it came across to my psych/therapist I only wanted a label."

b"5. I continued to drop a medication/dose here or there. But a couple years ago I saw someone speak about being bipolar as a dev. And while I could relate in some ways, other ways I couldn't  Grandiose thoughts? Too much energy to sleep? I could never relate"

b'4. I saw a new psych, seeing a smaller/weaker cocktail. And that I got! June 2014, when my life changed and I could actually *feel* happiness (and not just sad/anger)  And with that, I got a new dx as well: Bipolar II'

b'Oligodendrocytes insulate axonal fibers for fast conduction of nerve impulses. During development, bipolar oligodendroglial precursor cells transform into highly ramified multipolar mature oligodendrocytes with expand myelin membranes that enwrap axons.'

b'Like the 4th of July firework, oligodendrocytes light up the "sky" with spontaneous calcium spikes when they develop from immature bipolar precursors to mature multipolar oligodendrocytes with myelin membranes.'

b"Speaking of mental health and men (Bruce Willis, and other posts I've seen), @adaptivetexan joins me on Dad Talk to discuss being a dad with bipolar. We both open up and had a meaningful and necessary conversation.  https://t.co/n5hpddNeJn"

b"9. Do you have any words of advice for people in the world suffering with bipolar disorder, or other mental illness?  Don't give up so easily. That's not to say I wouldn't understand if you did. I would. But put up at least a little bit of a fight. Don't let this dx win so easily"

b'8. Have you ever felt discriminated against or looked poorly on because of bipolar disorder?  I don\'t know about discriminated... but certainly looked down upon. Because I was drinking, or "lazy," or smoking, or skipping town. My bx caused this, but the disease caused my bx.'

b"7. How do you think society treats people with a mental illness, especially bipolar disorder?  Like shit, a lot of the time. People either fear us or want to be us because of the media fetishizing the disease. We're either brilliant artists or violent criminals."

b"6. Has having bipolar disorder affected your friendships, personal life, or professional life?  Sure, how does it not? I'm much friendlier now that I am stable because I'm not so irritable all the time. That said, my interpersonal relationships are limited."

b'1. What does bipolar disorder mean to you?  It means I have experienced the more extreme side of human emotion; that I have been places in the human mind that most people will never go -- and made it back, which makes me stronger than I tend to give myself credit for.'

b'The hardest part of receiving my diagnosis was that all I knew about bipolar disorder was what I saw in the media. Often characterized as "crazy" or "out of control," I didn\'t want to be those things. Over the past few years I\'ve met so many amazing people with this diagnosis 6/'

b'Rather than experience high levels of energy, extreme happiness, or invincibility, my hypomania is mostly characterized by interrupted sleep, obsessive/racing thoughts, agitation, irritability, and anxiety. For a long time I just thought I was a stressed out jerk, not bipolar. 3/'

b'My bipolar disorder manifests in three states: depressive episodes, hypomanic episodes, or most commonly, for me, mixed episodes. It took me a long time to realize and to get diagnosed as bipolar because my hypomania and mixed episodes rarely look like what people think 2/'
